awd_titl_txt: NCS-FO: Analyzing Synapses, Motifs and Neural Networks for Large-Scale Connectomics
awd_abstract_narration:
High-resolution analysis of the brain's connectivity, which reveals the actual wiring diagram connecting nerve cells of the brain, provides insights unattainable any other way into the way the healthy brain works and what goes awry in diseases and disorders of the nervous system. The primary challenge of this approach is that at present there are no reliable, robust and powerful computer-based techniques to analyze the extraordinarily large and vastly complicated networks of brain cells to detect connectional motifs in their highly branching and connected structure. Nor are there visualization tools that allow neuroscientists to explore the brain network patterns effectively. This work will analyze large brain networks from electron microscopy datasets in young and old mammalian brain samples. These data sets each contains hundreds of thousands of nerve cells and billions of synapses that interconnect them. The proposal aims to develop new methods and tools to analyze these vast brain networks at the synapse, motif, and network levels. If successful, the project will provide data and analysis tools for the development of new theories of how the brain works.

Recent advances in image acquisition using multi-beam serial-section electron microscopy (sSEM) and automated segmentation methods have enabled data collection for large tissue samples in a variety of animals. These data will be used to curate large-scale datasets with one million labeled synapses with synaptic cleft locations, pre- and postsynaptic polarity predictions, and excitatory and inhibitory type predictions. This has not been accomplished previously given the enormous amount of data. The aim is to discover synaptic motifs by subdividing complex neural networks into quantifiable and meaningful subgraphs. Automatic generation of candidates for motifs will be created by developing an efficient neurite-centric wiring-diagram reconstruction method and subgraph detection algorithm to find common patterns. These data will be used to quantify and compare reconstructed neural networks from different specimens at different spatial and temporal scales and build a visualization platform to assist neuroscientists to analyze these networks as they seek to ask and answer fundamental questions related to neural circuits in the brain.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Connectomics is a new scientific discipline that reveals, at very high resolution, the actual wiring diagram connecting nerve cells of the brain. This field provides insights unattainable any other way into the way the healthy brain works and what goes awry in diseases and disorders of the nervous system. The primary challenge of this approach is that there were no reliable, robust, and powerful computer-based techniques to analyze the vast and complicated networks of brain cells to detect connectional motifs in their highly branching and connected structure. Nor were there visualization tools that would allow neuroscientists to explore the brain network patterns effectively. In this project, the PIs have developed new methods and tools to analyze and visualize these vast brain networks, leading to new theories of how the brain works.

The PIs have published new datasets with dense annotations of mitochondria, axon, and neuronal nuclei larger than previous benchmark datasets by at least two orders of magnitude. These datasets pose novel computer vision challenges that go well beyond existing benchmarks, attracting researchers from various backgrounds to develop new computational approaches for neuroscience. They also acquired and reconstructed a two-petabyte image volume in close collaboration with Google, one of the largest EM connectomics datasets ever collected. This data will yield new insights into the workings of the human brain.

On the computer science side, the PIs have developed active- and semi-supervised learning methods to improve reconstruction performance while minimizing the human annotation cost. Their semi-supervised synaptic cleft detection algorithm ranks 1st and outperforms previous state-of-the-art methods by 6.1% on the public CREMI challenge leaderboard. The PIs also developed novel algorithms for error correction, interactive proofreading, synapse-aware skeletonization, topological shape analysis, and motif discovery in large connectomic networks. A new open-source package called PyTorch Connectomics provides a scalable and flexible deep learning toolbox to tackle feature detection and segmentation tasks in connectomics. The package contains detailed tutorials for computer science and neuroscience researchers to efficiently adapt state-of-the-art computer vision algorithms to new neuroscience data with little coding. PyTorch connectomics and a newly developed visualization tool for proofreading will assist neuroscientists as they seek to ask and answer fundamental questions about neural circuits in the brain.

The PIs have incorporated the results of this research into the curricula of existing courses in visualization and data science, enhancing senior undergraduate and graduate student education. The funding has been used to support several Postdoctoral Fellows and Ph.D. students who were an integral part of this project's research and educational endeavors.
